project.name: |---- 009-lounge-css-classes
project.description:
This project builds on 008-lounge-css and incorporates some additional CSS features such as CSS classes.
CSS: each CSS statement consists of a location, a property on that location and a style to apply to that property.
CSS statements are called rules.
Rules can be combined using comma:
h1, h2 { color: gray; }
Rules can appear multiple times for the same location.
The location is called the selector
The elements within a block element for which a style is defined inherit the styles. For example, elements defined within p inherit the CSS rules defined for p. If you move it further up to the body, then all elements will be affected.
Inheritance can be overridden by specifying a different rule for a given element.
The browser knows which rule to apply by using 'the most specific' rule. If there is a rule for body and a more specific rule for p, the rule for p will be applied.
The project leverages on 007-lounge-html5 to include links to a CSS file named lounge.css.
This CSS contains very basic styles (font family, colors, horizontal lines, etc.)
CSS classes to style differently elements of the same type (paragraphs, headings, etc.). To use CSS classes you have to modify the element and also use class selectors in your CSS.
CSS Validator can be found at: http://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/
Common Properties: + background-color : controls the background color of an element + background-image : use this property to put an image behind an element + border : puts a border around an element - solid, dotted, ridged... + color : sets the font color for text elements + font-size : makes text bigger or smaller + font-style : use this property to make the font italic or oblique + font-weight : the weight of the text, for example, to make it bold + left : how you tell an element how to position its left side + letter-spacing : controls the spacing between letters l i k e t h i s + line-height : sets the space between lines in a text element + list-style : to change how list items look in a list + padding : use this property if you need space between the edge of an element and its content + text-align : use this property to align your text to the left, center or right + top : controls the position of the top of the element
